metadata.case_name: Petitioners (Dealers in motor spirit) v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Petitioners are dealers in motor spirit in Hyderabad.

In 1949 the Hyderabad Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation Regulation, No. XXIV of 1358 Fasli (the Regulation) was passed and the petitioners were registered as retail dealers of petroleum products under the Regulation.

In 1957 the petitioners and others filed writ petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh questioning the validity of the Regulation. There was also a prayer for stay of the levy and collection of the tax and the High Court ordered that all further proceedings in the matter of levy, demand and collection of tax including cancellation of registration certificate and threatened attachment of property and the launching of criminal proceedings in pursuance of the Regulation be stayed.

Petitioners allege that on this stay being granted by the High Court, they thought that S. 3 of the Regulation was suspended during the period of stay and therefore they stopped collecting the tax from consumers.

While these petitions were pending in the High Court, the Madras Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation (Andhra Pradesh Extension and Amendment) Act, No. V of 1958 (the Act), was passed by which the Madras Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation Act, No. VI of 1939 was applied to Andhra Pradesh with some modifications and the Regulation was repealed. This Act, like the Regulation, had provisions for registration of dealers and in consequence fresh registration certificates were issued to the petitioners as well as to all other dealers in the State.
In August 1958 the petitions challenging the validity of the Regulation were dismissed.

In September 1958 notices were issued to the petitioners informing them that they had failed to submit returns showing sales of motor spirit from March 1957 to March 1958 and they were required to submit returns within seven days, failing which best judgment assessments would be made under the relevant provision of the Regulation.

The petitioners made representations against this order and their main case was that they had not collected any tax from consumers during this period and it would therefore be harsh to demand tax from them in the circumstances.
Best judgment assessments were made against the petitioners and they were required to pay the tax, though liberty to pay in installments was granted to them for this purpose.

As the petitioners failed to deposit the tax even in installments, the registration certificate of one of the petitioners was cancelled and other petitioners were threatened with cancellation of their registration certificates about October 1959.
Consequently, the present petitions were filed soon after challenging the provisions of the Act relating to cancellation of registration certificates.
The respondents say that the allegation of the petitioners that they did not collect the tax during the period of the stay orders from consumers is false.

legal_issues.text: Whether sub-ss. (1) and (6) of s. 4 of the Act and r. 14 purported to be framed thereunder are ultra vires as being violative of Art. 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cancellation of registration certificates results in the total extinction of the business of the person whose registration is cancelled and thus the provision as to cancellation is an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on business under Art. 19(1)(g).

respondent_arguments.text: The provisions in question are reasonable restrictions on the right guaranteed under Art. 19(1)(g) and are therefore perfectly valid and constitutional.
The allegation of the petitioners that they did not collect the tax during the period of the stay orders from consumers is false.

court_reasoning.text: The purpose and object of the Act is to levy and collect tax on retail sales of motor spirit in the interest of the general revenues of the State. Section 4(1) provides for registration of dealers who carry on the business in motor spirit. Without such registration it would be impossible for the State to know the persons who are selling motor spirit and from whom the tax is due. The provision therefore under s. 4(1) for registration of dealers is an eminently reasonable provision in order to carry out the object of the Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Registration is necessary for tax collection and is not a restriction; anyone can get registered.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-s. (6) provides that any registration under sub-s. (1) may be suspended or cancelled by such authority, for such reasons, and in such manner, as may be prescribed. Rule 14 provides conditions under which the registration may be cancelled, including failure to pay the tax or fraudulently evading payment. Cancellation of registration for failure to pay the tax or for fraudulently evading the payment of it is an additional coercive process which is expected to be immediately effective and enables the State to realise its revenues which are necessary for carrying on the administration in the interest of the general public.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cancellation is a reasonable coercive method for tax recovery, even if it results in extinction of business in some cases.

court_reasoning.text: Referring to Narendra Kumar v. The Union of India, the word restriction in Arts. 19(5) and 19(6) includes cases of prohibition also; where a restriction reaches the stage of total restraint of rights special care has to be taken to see that the test of reasonableness is satisfied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applying the tests, cancellation is justified as it is in respect of a tax meant for general revenues.

court_reasoning.text: Though there is no provision in the Act or the Rules specifically authorising the seller to pass on the tax to the consumer, what actually happens is that the seller includes the tax in the price and thus passes it on to the consumer. The dealer has already collected the tax and the compulsion of payment via cancellation is justified.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fault lies with the dealer for non-payment.

holdings.text: The challenge to the constitutionality of s. 4(1) must fail as registration is eminently reasonable.
Sub-s. (6) of s. 4 and r. 14 are constitutional as they impose reasonable restrictions under Art. 19(1)(g).

precedents_cited.case_name: Narendra Kumar v. The Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that restriction includes prohibition; test of reasonableness for total restraint considering nature of evil, harm to individual vs. benefit to public.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions challenged as violative of right to carry on business; restrictions justified in interests of general public.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation (Andhra Pradesh Extension and Amendment) Act, No. V of 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Act to levy tax on retail sales; registration, payment, cancellation provisions for enforcement.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Sales of Motor Spirit Taxation Regulation, No. XXIV of 1358 Fasli
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed by the Act; prior law under which petitioners were registered and challenged.

outcome.summary: The petitions challenging the constitutionality of sub-ss. (1) and (6) of s. 4 of the Act and r. 14 as violative of Art. 19(1)(g) are dismissed as the provisions are held to be reasonable restrictions.

key_quotes.text: The provision therefore under s. 4(1) for registration of dealers is an eminently reasonable provision in order to carry out the object of the Act, namely, the levy and collection of this tax for purposes of the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Cancellation of registration for failure to pay the tax or for fraudulently evading the payment of it is an additional coercive process which is expected to be immediately effective and enables the State to realise its revenues.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The fault for failure to pay the tax or fraudulent evasion in payment thereof lies in the circumstances entirely on the dealer and he cannot be heard to complain that cancellation of registration in such a case is a disproportionate restriction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
